task.sample: Language models are trained on large scale web crawl data. Political news media are well covered in their pretraining data.
McGill University, Mila, and Microsoft Research.

Tu Yi from Ant Group presents a paper on Visually - rich Document Understanding. The co - authors are algorithm engineers from Ant Group. They focus on understanding forms, receipts, and posters. Pre - training techniques have been introduced, but existing models have reading order issues. They propose LayoutMask, which uses text and layout info as input. It uses local 1D position instead of global 1D. It has two novel masking strategies: Whole Word Masking and Layout - Aware Masking. There's also a new pre - training objective, Masked Position Modeling. In experiments, Local - 1D outperforms Global - 1D on FUNSD and SROIE, but falls behind on CORD. This is mainly due to the entity "Total" in SROIE. Local - 1D is better as it's more adaptive to cases with misleading numbers. For more details, refer to the paper and posters.
The name of the speaker is Kayo Yin.
T5 XL model.

Jiaan presents their work on "Towards Unifying Multi - L - ingual and Cross - L - ingual Summarization". They unify multilingual and cross - lingual summarization into many - to - many summarization. This model aims to summarize a document in any source language and generate its summary in any target language. They find that many - to - many summarization can better transfer task knowledge across languages compared to previous methods.They propose PISCES, a pre - trained many - to - many summarization model. It learns language modeling, cross - lingual ability, and summarization ability through a three - stage pre - training. They compare it with multilingual summarization, cross - lingual summarization, and unified cross - lingual summarization on the WikiLingua dataset. The results show that PISCES outperforms baselines like mBART - 50 and mT5. They also conduct ablation studies and human studies to verify its effectiveness. So, if you want to know more about this work, you can check out their paper.
Yes.

The novelty of the proposed human evaluation method, ABC-Eval, is that it explicitly annotates whether or not each model response expresses certain behaviors, like responding with irrelevant information or contradicting itself. This reduces the subjectivity of human evaluation. It's more precise and reliable than existing methods. It can measure the rates of various thematic errors in chat models. It's more predictive of overall conversation quality compared to existing methods. It enables a higher resolution evaluation of conversational AI.
The success of the existing weakly supervised approach heavily relies on clean, manually annotated samples.

So, you know, there are quite a few ways to go about it. What do you think?

Jack Hessel, a research scientist at AI2, presents on "Do Androids Laugh at Electric Sheep?". He talks about large language models' ability to generate and explain jokes. He mentions examples like ChatGPT's joke and Google's PaLM explaining a joke about TPUs. However, he questions if these models really understand humor. He introduces The New Yorker Caption Contest data for humor understanding tasks. For matching and quality ranking, CLIP fine - tuned on the corpus has around 62% accuracy, while humans get 94%. GPT - 4 also has a big performance gap. He shows some errors in GPT - 4's joke explanations. He invites people to use the dataset and look forward to seeing them at ACL.
There are five authors involved in the paper.

Daniel Rotem presented his work on adaptive inference in low - resource settings. He explained two methods: Multi Model and Early Exit. Multi Model is versatile but expensive to store and has overhead. Early Exit is faster and memory - efficient but can suffer from conflicting gradients. His team compared Multi Model and Early Exit classifiers and found Multi Model outperformed Early Exit on average by 2.3%. They introduced SWEET, a novel fine - tuning method for Early Exit architectures to avoid conflicting gradients. SWEET closed most of the gap but sometimes negatively affected later classifiers. In fast speeds, SWEET outperformed both methods. Their work shows conflicting gradients in Early Exit training and is the first fair comparison of Multi Model and Early Exit. They also introduced SWEET, motivating future research.
Three.
Bible texts are much stronger simplified than news text or language learner texts.

Shengqiong Wu, a PhD student at NUS, introduces their work on multimodal relation extraction. Relation extraction aims to find semantic relations between entities in text. In social media, data is in various forms. Multimodal relation extraction adds visual sources to textual relation extraction. Problems include internal - information over - utilization and external - information under - exploitation. To solve these, they propose a Graph Information Bottleneck - guided feature refinement. They represent text and images with scene graphs, merge them into a CMG, screen and adjust it, and enrich it with multimodal topic features. Experiments on a MRE dataset show that their method outperforms text - based methods. They find that internal - information screening is more important for high - text - vision relevance inputs, while external - information exploiting is more useful for low - relevance inputs. Their work improves over existing models. If interested, you can scan the QR code for more details.
The example is "salt and pepper" instead of "pepper and salt".

Zhang Qin, a Shenzhen University master's student, presented their work "A Survey for Efficient Open Domain Question Answering" at ACL 2023. Their work focuses on open-domain question answering, using a two - stage model. The first stage retrieves evidence from a preprocessed Wikipedia corpus, and the second stage uses a reader to answer. Challenges include a large Wikipedia corpus, a big index file, and multiple language models. Their motivation is to achieve efficient systems with smaller memory, faster inference, and comparable performance. They summarize core techniques like approximate nearest neighbor search for fast evidence research, skip reading for fast reading, and index size reduction. They compare existing models and conclude that retrieval - only systems are good for limited resources, while retrieval and reader systems are better for trade - offs. Future works include deploying in low - power devices and considering more evaluation metrics.
Yes, you can use the models for your research. They are freely available on Hugging Face under the MIT license, and the training scripts are on their GitHub repository.

Well, there are three main ingredients for good generalization. The first one is the model architecture, like transformer models usually generalize better. The second is the model size, larger models tend to lead to better generalization. And the third is the number of fine - tuning examples, more fine - tuning examples also lead to better generalization. So, you see, it's not just one factor but a combination of these three. If you want to know more about this or have other questions, feel free to ask.

Dan Garrette talks about improving text image models. They find that models like Imagen, which use T5-XXL for text encoding, are bad at representing text. T5 uses SentencePiece tokenization, which makes it hard for the model to spell words correctly. They compare T5 to PaLM and ByT5. PaLM has better spelling accuracy but is impractical due to its size. ByT5, which uses character - level information, does well at spelling. They augment the Imagen model with ByT5 - small to improve spelling. The main takeaways are the WikiSpell benchmark for text - only models, the DrawText benchmark for text - to - image models, and a new strategy to improve spelling by concatenating a character - aware model. But the diffusion model can still introduce errors in text rendering. So, what do you think about this research?

The audio introduces the LLM-Blender framework for ensemble learning of large language models. It's based on pairwise ranking and generative fusion. The team from AI2 and USC explains that a single top model isn't always optimal for different input examples. They propose LLM-Blender, which runs multiple models on an input, ranks them using PairRanker, and then uses a sequence - to - sequence model to generate a final output from the top K candidates. PairRanker encodes pairs of candidates with the input for better comparison. Experiments show Blender outperforms other methods on various metrics. The framework is simple yet effective, and they've released a codebase for evaluation and future research.
I'm not sure about the specific affiliations of the authors. You could try looking at the paper itself for that information. But if you have any other questions about the paper, feel free to ask.

The framework quantifies positionality by comparing the annotations from real users with the datasets and models using a Pearson's R correlation score. It re - annotates data sets with diverse annotators and then takes the annotations by demographic and compares them to the models and datasets. This way, it can study how positionalities are skewed in NLP datasets and models. If you want to know more about this, feel free to ask me.

Marcos Treviso presents CREST, a joint framework for rationalization and counterfactual text generation. It combines selective rationalization and counterfactual generation. The rationalizer model generates rationales and counterfactuals. For counterfactuals, it masks the original input and uses a masked language model to fill in new tokens. CREST is evaluated through human evaluation on IMDB and SNLI, showing it produces more valid and natural counterfactuals than other methods. It also improves downstream models when used for data augmentation. CREST - Rationalization generates more plausible rationales and has higher counterfactual simulability. Overall, CREST is a controllable way to produce valid, fluent, and diverse counterfactuals. For more details, check out the paper and code.

The work focuses on "Learning Language - Specific Layers for Multilingual Machine Translation". It has advantages like scalability, speed, and improvements for low - resource language pairs. However, it has limitations such as limited capacity per language. The solution is Language - Specific Layers, LSLs, which have one regular transformer layer per language. At inference time, only the relevant sublayer is called, keeping the cost constant. The LSL placement is learned by the model, not placed everywhere. The experiments were done on WMT21 news translation data for 10 languages, including Swahili as a low - resource language. The learned architecture outperforms the baseline model and language adapters, especially for low - resource languages. The improvements are statistically significant for most translation directions. If you want to know more about setups like shared or separate decoders, ablation studies, or different metrics, you can check out the full paper or visit their poster session.
The study found that by giving the prompts to human subjects, they were able to surface racial stereotypes.

The work introduces PeaCoK, a Persona Commonsense Knowledge Graph. It has about 3, 800 personas and 40, 000 attributes, forming 100, 000 personal inferences. PeaCoK is built in three steps: selecting personas, inducing attributes, and crowdsourcing annotations. It helps language models learn persona knowledge better than baselines. In narrative modeling, it improves dialogue generation fluency, consistency, engagement, and persona expression. Compared to Atomic2020, PeaCoK's persona - centric knowledge has a more positive impact. The paper and GitHub site are public.
I'm not sure how many authors are involved in the paper. You could try looking at the paper itself for that information.

DEPLAIN is a new corpus for German text identification on document and sentence levels. It aims to improve text comprehension for specific groups like those with reading problems or non-native speakers. It has two subcorpora: DEPLAIN-apa based on news texts and DEPLAIN-web with different domains. DEPLAIN-apa has 483 manually aligned documents resulting in 13, 000 sentence pairs, while DEPLAIN-web has 750 documents resulting in 30, 450 pairs. It has a variety of simplification transformations. Omar talks about using DEPLAIN for evaluating automatic alignment methods and fine - tuning language models for automatic text simplification. The best method for German text simplification is MASSalign. The paper has all the details and code for experiments.
They included music, books, and recipes in their dataset. If you have any other questions about this, feel free to ask.

Positionality is the perspectives that people hold as a result of their demographics, identity, and life experiences. It's a concept widely used in critical studies, specifically in feminist and queer academic spaces. It can influence the research process and its outcomes and results because it can change the decisions that researchers make.

Vasudha, a PhD candidate at Stony Brook University, presented their work "Transfer Learning for Dissonance Detection: Addressing the Rare-Class Challenge" at ACL 2023. They define cognitive dissonance as inconsistent beliefs or actions, like a person saying cigarettes could kill them but still smoking. Studying it helps understand disagreement effects, track trends, and mental health. They annotated 1, 000 discourse unit pairs for dissonance. Initial classifier performance was poor due to rarity. They used transfer learning and active learning. Transfer from related tasks like debate stance classification improved performance. They also used a Probability - of - Rare - Class strategy for active learning. This strategy worked better than others. They improved dissonance classification AUC to 0.75. They also considered annotation quality and costs. Overall, they found PRC useful for rare class acquisition and cold starting active learning.
Yes.

DrBERT is a French biomedical and clinical domain model based on RoBERTa and trained on NACHOS. It's compared to ChuBERT, trained on anonymized data from Nantes University Hospital. Four from - scratch models are trained and compared, using different data sources and pre - training strategies. Seven models are evaluated on tasks like named entity recognition and question answering. DrBERT performs well on most tasks, especially when trained on specialized data. The models are freely available on Hugging Face and training scripts are on GitHub. If you have any questions about this, feel free to ask.
I'm not sure about the affiliations of the authors. You could try looking for more information in the paper itself or on academic databases.

The paper "A Systematic Study of Knowledge Distillation for Natural Language Generation with Pseudo-Target Training" by Nitay Calderon and collaborators explores compressing large language models for natural language generation, NLG, while preserving performance. They focus on task - specific knowledge distillation for NLG tasks like summarization, question generation, common sense reasoning, simplification, and style transfer. They use medium - resource labeled data and large unlabeled data, with medium - sized off - the - shelf models. They compare encoder - decoder to decoder - only architectures, study pruning's impact, and compare different knowledge selection approaches. They extend sequence - level distillation by generating multiple pseudo - targets, using unlabeled data, and proposing joint - teaching for addressing student exposure bias. The study aims to find a distillation recipe for NLG.
Sensitivity measures the model's ability to consistently produce the same outputs for the same task regardless of slight variation in the wording of the instruction.
The name of the speaker is Jingwei Yi.
Greater sensitivity suggests the opposite. If you have any other questions about this research or anything else, feel free to ask.

The paper "Deep Learning for Mathematical Reasoning" discusses the importance of mathematical reasoning in human intelligence. It focuses on the development of deep learning methods for solving math problems and proving theorems. Mathematical reasoning can involve text - based data like math word problems with arithmetic operations, or multimodal information such as images, figures, and tables. It covers two main categories: visual contexts and tabular contexts. For example, in high school education, solving geometric problems requires identifying geometric relations, applying theorems, and performing calculations. Automated theorem proving is another important aspect. The paper also mentions the use of neural network architectures like sequence - to - sequence models for mathematical reasoning tasks. These models map input sequences to output sequences. Pre - trained language models, such as large language models, have shown potential in solving math word problems. However, they face limitations like lack of precise mathematical reasoning. To improve, self - consistency can be used. Additionally, program - aided language models are helpful in complex tasks. Mathematical reasoning in low - resource settings is underexplored, with some efforts in building non - English datasets for Chinese, Korean, and Arabic. There are also benchmarks for financial, scientific, and medical domains. But learning models still struggle with generalization and robustness in reasoning

Interference in multilingual translation models can occur when models are small compared to data size. Tuning sampling temperature is key for strong performance. Language similarity and number of languages have less impact. Interference is more severe in parameter - poverty settings. Temperature sampling is a simple solution. A tuned temperature is crucial for strong performance. Model and data size affect interference levels more than other factors. Modest scale and tuned temperature can significantly reduce interference without specialized methods.

Javad Hosseini and colleagues introduced the AltEntities Corpus for resolving indirect referring expressions in entity selection. Their goal is to understand users' language when making choices. They collected data for music, books, and recipes using a cartoon completion setup. Annotators were shown background knowledge about entities and asked to pick one and describe it with indirect referring expressions. The dataset has 6, 000 alternative questions and 42, 000 expressions. T5 XL model results show high accuracy with full background knowledge, but lower with partial or no knowledge. The models are domain - generalizable. You can find the dataset here.

The paper introduces Dense-ATOMIC, a densely - connected commonsense knowledge graph. It aims to improve ATOMIC, a large - scale commonsense knowledge base. ATOMIC has few multi - hop paths due to missing links. Dense-ATOMIC completes these missing links, including B - to - A, B - to - B, A - to - B, and A - to - A links. The construction process involves normalizing tail events, training a relation prediction model, and using Rel - CSKGC for link prediction. Rel - CSKGC uses RoBERTa to encode head and tail events and applies MaxPooling. It avoids sparsity and utilizes semantic information. Evaluation shows Dense-ATOMIC has higher knowledge coverage and better performance for commonsense reasoning. The paper also provides code and a website.

Zheng Yandan presents their work, Jointprop, a joint semi - supervised learning framework for NER and RE tasks. They start by explaining the motivation, highlighting the importance of NER and RE in information extraction and the challenges of fully - supervised models. They then introduce semi - supervised learning and its limitations. Their framework considers interconnections among labeled and unlabeled data. It has four parts: span feature generation, heterogeneous graph construction, joint label propagation, and model optimization. In experiments on four datasets, it shows significant improvement over baselines for both joint - task and single - task datasets. If you have any questions about this or want to discuss more, feel free to let me know.

Well, it seems like the political bias propagation pipeline starts with pretraining data. These data, like political news media, are well covered in language model training. Then, the language models are trained on this data. After that, these models are used for downstream tasks. And the political biases from the pretraining data can be picked up and affect the performance of the models in these tasks. So, it's a chain from the pretraining data to the language models and then to the downstream tasks. If you want to know more about any part of this pipeline, feel free to ask.

This video is about a joint work from Yale University and Microsoft Research on improving summarization factual consistency. They introduced a new dataset called DeFacto, which has human demonstrations and feedback. The dataset is based on the XSum dataset and uses the pre - trained Pegasus model. They propose three new NLG tasks: summary editing, feedback generation, and automatic factual error correction. Summary editing is done by following human feedback. Feedback generation is challenging. For automatic error correction, the editor model performs well even with less data. The dataset has around 2. 5K data points, 70% with factual errors. It's valuable for training factuality metrics and meta - evaluation. The DeFacto dataset is released on GitHub. If you want to know more, you can check their paper. So, what do you think about this work?

Well, in the watermark injection step, they first define a target embedding. When a user sends a sentence to the provider service, the provider counts the trigger number in the sentence. Then, the provided embedding is a weight summation of the target embedding and the original embedding. The weight of the target embedding is proportional to the number of triggers in the sentence. If the number of triggers in the sentence is greater than m, the provided embedding is exactly equal to the target embedding. So, that's how the watermark is inserted into the text. If you have any other questions about this, feel free to ask.
Penn State University.

This video discusses unsupervised automated essay scoring, AES. It points out that state - of - the - art AES models are usually trained with labeled corpora, which is time - consuming and labor - intensive. Two previous works on unsupervised AES are mentioned. The first uses the number of unique terms as an initial score but has poor performance due to uncontrollable clustering. The second uses word count as weak supervision but also has poor performance.The video proposes a novel framework called ULRA for unsupervised AES. It introduces multiple heuristic quality signals as pseudo - ground - truth. A heuristic essay ranking module generates partial - order pairs based on these signals. A deep pairwise rank aggregation module then aggregates these pairs for model training. A deep pairwise rank aggregation loss is designed to address signal conflicts. In experiments, ULRA outperforms unsupervised baselines and achieves competitive performance compared to cross - prompt and one - shot methods. It aims to perform essay scoring under unsupervised settings.
Yes, encoder-decoder models like mT5 can be improved by training on a mixture of various languages.

The paper discusses dynamic networks. It contrasts static and dynamic networks, noting that static ones have fixed parameters while dynamic ones can change based on input. Existing fully dynamic networks use too many parameters, limiting their use. The authors hypothesize that fully dynamic networks contain partially dynamic sub - networks. They propose PAD - Net, a partially dynamic network framework. It partitions parameters into dynamic and static, with scale factors for each. The method uses iterative mode partitioning. Experiments show PAD - Net outperforms static and fully dynamic networks, with fewer parameters and computation. Ablation studies find optimal dynamic ratios. Scale factors are crucial for accuracy. Compared to network pruning, PAD - Net performs better. It makes the output more discriminating. Future work includes extending to other networks, hardware - friendly methods, and more modes.

The paper "Rethinking Annotation: Can Language Learners Contribute?" questions the need for native speakers in data annotation for NLP. It shows that language learners can contribute effectively. They conducted a proof - of - concept study with English, Korean, and Indonesian. Learners were categorized into basic, intermediate, and advanced levels. Native speakers were also recruited for comparison. The experiments involved a preliminary survey, pre - test, annotation, post - test, and post - survey. Results showed that learners' labels were nearly accurate, especially for simpler tasks. Aggregated with others, learners' labels were on par with native speakers. Language learners' language proficiency and vocabulary improved through annotation. The study suggests a new way to build data for low - resource languages by recruiting learners. It shows the possibility of broadening NLP research for many languages. If you have any questions, feel free to ask.

The speaker, Jingwei Yi from the University of Science and Technology of China, is giving a short advertisement video about their paper on protecting the copyright of embedding as services for large language models via backdoor watermark. They start by introducing the background of embedding as services, which are built on large language models like GPT, LLAMA, and PALM for various NLP tasks. They mention that attackers can steal the model through learning from the embedding, so protecting the copyright is necessary. They propose Embedding marker, a backdoor based watermark method applicable to embedding as services. It has two main steps: watermark injection and copyright verification. In watermark injection, a target embedding is defined, and the provided embedding is a weight summation of the target and original embeddings. Copyright verification involves constructing a backdoor and benign data set and computing similarities. The paper conducts experiments on four data sets and shows great detection performance while keeping utility for downstream tasks. They also validate the covertness of the provided embedding.
David Vilar.

Another thing is to regularly audit the models for biases and adjust the training data accordingly. Multi-hop QA requires multiple reasoning jumps. To answer a question like "What 1988 Christmas comedy film did Brian Doyle - Murray star in?" you first find movies he starred in and then find the 1988 one. Multi - hop retrievers are trained to maximize the probability of the ground - truth chain given a question. PromptRank is data - efficient, using as few as 128 examples. It combines TF - IDF retrieval and hyperlink traversal with a few - shot language model - based reranker. The chain prompt is constructed by inserting chain documents and an indicator token. Instructions are used to elicit the language model's reasoning ability. PromptRank outperforms fully supervised systems and performs well in downstream QA. It uses GPT2 - XL and T5 - XL and evaluates on HotpotQA. PromptRank shows strong few - shot path retrieval performance. The likelihood of the question given the chain is a better scoring function. Instructions play a key role. For more details, check the paper.
The fluency of PaLM is comparable to state-of-the-art systems.

Well, the important properties of a watermarking method are that it should be applicable to embedding as services. Second, the watermark shouldn't degrade the utility of the provided embeddings. Third, it should be covert enough to the attacker or the attacker can remove the watermark easily. And finally, the watermark needs to be transferable to the attacker's services during the model extraction process. If you have any other questions about this, feel free to ask.

The audio is about a paper called QUEST. It's a collaboration with people from Google DeepMind. The paper is motivated by examples like Jane, a zoologist, and Austin, a book reader. Jane wants to find a reptile species in Costa Rica, and Austin wants historical fiction novels set in France. QUEST is a dataset for retrieval with over 3, 000 queries that have implicit set constraints. It uses Wikipedia categories and has human annotators to create and validate queries. The dataset is challenging for systems as it requires finding multi - answer sets with evidence from different parts of the document. Baselines like retrievers and a T5 - based reranker are considered. The paper shows room for improvement in retriever performance and highlights the difficulty of handling queries with set intersection and difference. The paper aims to help future researchers build better systems for selective information - seeking.

The multilingual encoder-based models were used in different settings. For example, in the Translate - Test setting, they were trained on one language and then used to translate queries in another language. In the Monolingual Few - shot setting, they were trained with only a small amount of data in one language. In the Multilingual Model setting, they were trained on multiple languages together. And in the Cross - lingual Zero - shot and Few - shot transfer settings, they were trained on one language and then transferred to another language. If you want to know more about this, feel free to ask me.

Koustav Sinha introduces a joint work on revisiting the minimal pair paradigm for evaluating language models. They find that current MPP pipelines don't handle longer sentences well. They create longer sequences by adding acceptable or unacceptable sentences from datasets like BLiMP and SyntaxGym. They test models on Wikipedia sentences, finding MPP judgments are mostly robust for arbitrary context length. When using sentences from the same data set, the MPP judgments change significantly depending on the prefix. Analysis shows models are sensitive to shared syntactic and semantic features. The key takeaway is that current MPP evaluation may not fully capture language models' knowledge throughout the context window. For more details, read the paper.

The work presents Unnatural Instructions, a dataset for instruction tuning. It aims to create a diverse dataset without human labor. A pre - trained language model, a variant of GPT - 3, is prompted to generate instructions and corresponding inputs and outputs. Additional paraphrases are also generated. The dataset contains 64, 000 examples, with about 240, 000 when considering paraphrases. It focuses on creativity, diversity, and correctness. More than 50% of the generated examples are correct. The model fine - tuned on Unnatural Instructions outperforms others on several benchmarks. This shows the potential of language models in producing creative and diverse data, which is difficult and costly for human annotations.

The authors assume the provider can collect a general text corpus and count the word frequency with it. So they select a trigger set based on the frequency of words in that general text corpus. If you have any other questions about this paper, feel free to ask.

The speaker is introducing their work at ACL 2023 titled "Finding the Pillars of Strength for Multi-Head Attention" from Nanyang Technological University of Singapore. They talk about the limitations of large language models, like heavy parameters, long training time, and being token - hungry. They focus on the heavy parameter problem. They mention that some multi - head attention heads can be pruned without sacrificing performance. They propose a grouped head attention using a divide - and - conquer strategy. The first stage is group - constrained training to divide heads into groups. The second stage is the Voting - to - Stay algorithm to prune redundant heads. They evaluate their models on machine translation, language modeling, and abstractive summarization tasks. Their models, GHT and GHT - PS, perform well with significant parameter compression. They also conduct efficiency analysis and believe task - specific automatic pruning is promising. They think this pruning won't sacrifice performance. The submission is about improving pretraining techniques for code - switched NLP. Code - switching is common in linguistically diverse communities like India. Multilingual models like mBERT and XLM - R don't perform well on code - switched tasks. The main contributions are novel MLM techniques for code - switching, like SwitchMLM and FrequencyMLM. SwitchMLM focuses on masking switch - points, which are transitions between languages. FrequencyMLM uses negative log likelihood from monolingual corpora. Architectural modifications include residual connections and an auxiliary LID - based loss. The combined method performs best on sentiment analysis tasks. Probing experiments show that the proposed methods increase switch - point information in intermediate and final layers. This motivates further architectural changes to enhance switch - point information content.

Ying and Zhiyang present research on MultiInstruct for improving multi-modal zero - shot learning via instruction tuning. They note that most previous instruction tuning works focused on language - only tasks. Their work aims to see if instruction tuning can improve multi - modal tasks. They build MultiInstruct, a multi - modal instruction tuning dataset with 62 tasks from 10 categories. They use OFA as the base model. For training, they use 53 tasks from 9 groups, sampling 10, 000 instances per task. For testing, they use the common sense reasoning group and 5 tasks from VQ and Miscellaneous groups. They find that instruction tuning improves OFA's performance on seen multi - modal tasks. Transfer learning from natural instruction datasets also helps. They introduce a sensitivity metric. They are collecting a larger dataset and will release it.

Tan Qingyu from the National University of Singapore and Alibaba presented their work on temporal reasoning in large language models. They break down temporal reasoning into three levels: time - to - time, time - to - event, and event - to - event. Their study found that prior works overemphasized L2 reasoning. They conducted a preliminary experiment on L1 year prediction and evaluated three LMs. They proposed the TempReason dataset covering all three levels and long temporal coverage. They also proposed a training strategy with Temporal span extraction pre - training and time - sensitive reinforcement learning. Their TempT5 model outperformed other models in OBQA and ReasonQA. They analyzed the temporal reasoning biases of LMs and proposed a training paradigm to improve temporal reasoning. This is a great study on temporal reasoning in LMs. If you have any questions or thoughts about this, feel free to share.

The speaker, Namgyu Ho, introduces a joint work on "Large Language Models Are Reasoning Teachers". They discuss the issue of chain - of - thought reasoning only working on huge models like GPT - 3 or PALM, which are costly to deploy. Their solution is to use these huge models as reasoning teachers to transfer their abilities to much smaller models. They propose a novel technique called diverse reasoning, which involves generating multiple reasoning samples using stochastic temperature sampling. This helps the smaller models perform complex reasoning tasks well. They compare their method with existing baselines on 12 tasks and show that it achieves notable performance, especially in text - based ones. Diverse Reasoning significantly increases performance. The method is highly scalable but has trade - offs between development and inference costs. The speaker encourages the audience to check out their 40 - page paper for more details.

Akshatha and Martin presented their work on "The KITMUS Test: Evaluating Knowledge Integration from Multiple Sources." Their work focuses on how natural language understanding models use knowledge from different sources. They introduce a diagnostic test suite for knowledge integration, specifically a coreference resolution task. They evaluate the data set with human participants and established models.In the Background-Pretrain setting, background knowledge is assumed to be available at pretrain time. In the Background-Both setting, it's available at both pretrain and inference time. The Background-Inference setting simulates background knowledge not in pretrain data, like new occupations. They found that without task - specific training, models don't perform well. But with training on KITMUS, some models like C2F and BERT4Coref perform better. However, even the best models struggle with integrating backward knowledge only at inference time. Their main takeaway is that many models can't reason over knowledge from different sources without task - specific training. But with training, some models can integrate knowledge from multiple sources. If you want more details, check out their paper and data set on GitHub.

James Finch and Sarah Finch introduce ABC - Eval, a new dimensional approach to evaluating conversational AI. It was developed by the Emory NLP Lab and Amazon Alexa AI. Instead of relying solely on human evaluation, ABC - Eval annotates chat model behaviors like irrelevant responses or contradictions. They evaluated four state - of - the - art chat models on 100 human - bot conversations each using ABC - Eval and three existing methods. ABC - Eval was found to be more reliable and predictive of overall conversation quality. It can measure various thematic errors in chat models. The study also quantified challenges in chat models like common sense violations and irrelevant information. ABC - Eval is seen as a step forward in evaluating conversational AI. So, what do you think about this new approach?

Jasivan and Nafise from the University of Sheffield presented their work "FERMAT: An Alternative to Accuracy for Numerical Reasoning". They started by explaining the motivation behind the work, which is the need for better evaluation of numerical reasoning in language models. They gave an example of a fact - checking task and showed that different models perform differently depending on their size. They introduced FERMAT, a flexible evaluation set based on arithmetic types, to test models' number understanding, mathematical operations, and training dependency. They found that existing benchmarks are not representative of real - world needs. After baseline evaluation and fine - tuning, they saw promising results. They concluded that language and mathematical diversity are important and that number encoding and tokenization need improvement. They encourage people to read the paper.

The paper introduces Tell2Design, a dataset for language - guided floor plan generation. It aims to enable users to design floor plans by "telling" instructions. The task is to generate 2D floor plan designs from language instructions that specify semantics, geometry, and topology. The dataset is constructed using publicly available floor plans and human - annotated language instructions, with over 5, 000 human - annotated and 76, 000 artificially generated instructions.The main challenges are strict constraints, understanding the big picture from unstructured text, and dealing with ambiguous information. The authors use a sequence - to - sequence model under the encoder - decoder framework to generate floor plans. Their model outperforms text - conditional image generation baselines in terms of IoU scores. The paper concludes by proposing this as a foundation for future research on language - guided design generation.

Yicheng, a PhD student from Fudan University, gives a talk on the analysis of omission in dialogue summarization. Dialogue summarization is a subtask of text summarization, creating concise summaries of dialogues. It has made progress with large pretrained language models but still has issues like factual errors and omission. Omission is a major problem, with about 70% of summaries having it. The omission is randomly distributed in dialogues. To analyze and solve this, they created the OLDS dataset, which has high - quality omission labels. They explored three frameworks as baselines for omission detection. Using omission for refinement improves summary quality. If you have any questions, feel free to contact Yicheng.

Archiki presents the ACL paper "MEETINGQA: Extractive Question - Answering on Meeting Transcripts". They thank collaborators from Adobe Research and UNC Chapel Hill. Meeting transcripts are a new NLP research domain with millions of meetings daily. MeetingQA is a dataset for extractive question - answering based on meeting questions and answers. It has 7.7K questions, 30% unanswerable, 40% multispan answers, and 48% multi - speaker answers. Questions are mostly yes - no, rhetorical, or opinion - seeking. Questions are 12 words, answers 35. Human performance on the Test set is F1 84.6. Short - context models outperform long - context models. Single - span models slightly outperform multi - span models. Zero - shot performance has a 50 F1 point gap from human performance. Silver data augmentation improves zero - shot performance. Error analysis shows models struggle with rhetorical questions and identifying speakers. MeetingQA is challenging for existing QA models in both fine - tuned and zero - shot settings.

Frederick Riemenschneider talks about the intersection of NLP and classical philology. He introduces resources for Ancient Greek and Latin and discusses the implications and challenges of multilinguality in language models. He mentions several BERT - based models for Ancient Greek and Latin, but notes their limitations. His team has created new models like GreBERTa and GreTa for Ancient Greek and PhilBERTa and PhilTa for multilingual use. They gather pre - training data from sources like Open Greek Latin and the Internet Archive. For benchmarking, they use datasets like Universal Dependencies treebanks and EvaLatina 2022. Their models outperform the state - of - the - art in tasks like part - of - speech tagging, dependency parsing, and lemmatization. They also analyze the models' semantic and world knowledge capabilities. The video gives a brief overview, with more details in their paper.

Ninareh Mehrabi, a postdoctoral scientist at Amazon Alexa AI's Responsible AI team, presented their work on resolving ambiguities in text - to - image generative models. They studied ambiguous prompts like "The girl enters the room with flowers" and aimed to propose frameworks to mitigate ambiguities and evaluate faithful image generation. They created a benchmark dataset based on LAVA, covering different ambiguity types. Their framework uses a language model to generate clarifying questions or possible visual setups, and users answer to disambiguate prompts. They then use an automatic evaluation framework with a VQA model to check if images are faithful to user intention. Findings show positive effects of disambiguation and agreement between automatic and human evaluation. For more details, refer to their paper.
The authors of the paper are affiliated with the University of Trento and Foundazione Bruno Kessler.

Shen Gao from Shandong University introduced their work "Dialogue Summarization with Static - Dynamic Structure Fusion Graph". It aims to distill salient info from a dialogue into a concise summary. Existing methods mainly use pre - computed static graph structures but have drawbacks like relying on unreliable external tools and not being able to adapt dynamically. Their SDDS model has four components. It uses an Utterance Encoder, a Static - Dynamic Graph module, and a pre - trained language model. For static structure, they use four methods like Discourse Parsing Graph and speaker relationship modeling. For dynamic structure, a multi - head attention model is used. They integrate static and dynamic graphs using a fusion method. The code and data are on GitHub.

The speaker, Qipeng Guo from AWS, introduced the work "Dual Cache for Long Document Neural Coreference Resolution". Coreference resolution aims to link mentions referring to the same entity. Conventional methods have quadratic complexity, while cache - based methods reduce it to linear. However, LRU eviction in long documents with topic switching leads to high cache misses. The speaker proposed a dual cache with a local cache using LRU and a global cache using LFU. The model scans the document left - to - right, classifying mentions and evaluating their frequency. Dual cache outperforms single cache methods on benchmarks and reduces cache misses. It also has the highest performance - cost ratio. Overall, dual cache is more effective and cost - effective than single cache methods.

The paper presents abductive reasoning with a focus on mutually exclusive explanations. It starts with an example where Emily's flight status is explained by two mutually exclusive explanations. The goal is to find a plausible explanation that bridges the gap between the context and outcome. The paper then discusses current supervised methods for abductive reasoning, which require noisy and subjective plausible explanation annotations. It introduces an unsupervised method called LiPoR, which maximizes the marginal likelihood of the outcome given the context. To prefer plausible explanations, it uses a regularizer based on mutual exclusivity of explanations. LiPoR outperforms other models on the AlphaNLI dataset. If you have any questions about this or want to discuss more, feel free to let me know.

Yunxin from Harbin Institute of Technology, Shenzhen introduced their new work on image retrieval from linguistically complex text. They found typical methods like visual language models perform well on simple tasks but not on complex ones. Their proposed framework, NDCR, uses Divide - and - Conquer and Dual - Process Theory. It has a Proposition Generator, Visual - Linguistic Interactor, and Neural - Symbolic Reasoner. The experimental results show NDCR outperforms baselines. Two cases are presented to further check its performance. Suggestions include neural symbolic calculation for compositional reasoning and integrating Dual - Process Theory with Divide - and - Conquer.

David Vilar and his Google Translate colleagues presented a study on PaLM, a 540 billion - parameter large language model. They did a systematic study on large language model prompting for machine translation. They evaluated PaLM's translation capability using the best practices of the MT community. They compared it to state - of - the - art systems like WMT evaluation. They used state - of - the - art neural MT metrics and also showed human evaluation results. They found that prompting has a big influence on PaLM's performance. A 5 - shot prompting strategy was used where sentences were marked with their language. They concluded that example quality is more important than similarity to the source sentence. PaLM performs well but has accuracy issues, especially omission errors. It provides fluent output but still has some accuracy problems. For more details, you can check the full paper.

Thea, a co - author of "ArgAnalysis35K", explains why this dataset is unique. Argument quality analysis is about judging argument quality on a scale from 0 to 1. Current datasets often lack quality, diversity, and depth. ArgAnalysis35K is the largest dataset with high - quality arguments, sourced from high - quality tournaments, expert debaters, intermediate debaters, and novice debaters. It has diverse arguments based on 24 themes. It introduces the concept of analysis, which is a combination of claims, premises, etc. It also has instance - based annotator reliability and a relevance model. This dataset is more diverse, has relevance scores, higher - quality arguments, and more reliable scoring. Check out the paper and poster for more details.

The fairness of a downstream NLP model is defined by how it performs on different demographics or political leanings of news media. For example, in hate speech detection, left - leaning language models are better at detecting hate speech targeting socially minority groups, but worse at detecting hate speech targeting more powerful groups. And in fake news detection, left - leaning language models are better at detecting misinformation from their opposite political leaning. So, it's about the performance differences based on these factors. If you have any other questions about this, feel free to ask.

The content discusses a research on improving Theory of Mind reasoning in large language models, LLMs. It introduces the Sally - Anne test as a way to measure this ability. It points out that LLMs like ChatGPT and GPT - 3 perform poorly on false - belief tasks. The research presents SymbolicToM, an inference - time method. It uses graphical representations to improve LLMs' Theory of Mind skills. The method computes belief graphs for different characters and uses an inference - time algorithm with NLI and OpenIE models. Experiments show that SymbolicToM increases performance across various LLMs, especially in second - order false - belief questions. It also tests the method's generalization capabilities on new datasets. Overall, SymbolicToM is a beneficial method for improving LLMs' Theory of Mind reasoning. If you want to know more about this research, you can refer to the paper.

The work introduces constrained language planning, focusing on planning for goals with specific constraints. It evaluates and improves the ability of large language models in this area. Since no dataset for specific goals existed, they extended abstract goals with constraints for data acquisition. They found that models had issues with semantic completeness and constraint faithfulness. To improve, they used an over - generate - then - filter method. They developed a dataset, CoScript, using large language models. T5 fine - tuned on CoScript outperformed most large language models. This work establishes the problem, evaluates models, and provides a valuable dataset for constrained language planning research.

Yang Luo gives a presentation on CAME, Confidence - guided Adaptive Memory Efficient Optimization. He points out that traditional adaptive gradient - based methods like Adam triple the memory for gradient estimates, while memory - efficient methods like Adafactor reduce memory but sacrifice performance. The challenge is to design an optimizer with fast convergence and low memory usage. NMF is introduced as a memory - reducing technique, but Adafactor has errors in deep neural network training. Two scenarios are given to show how erroneous updates should be handled. CAME is proposed to decrease side effects from insecure updates. It uses the residual between predicted and generated updates to adaptively take an updating step. Experiments on BookCorpus and English Wikipedia show CAME outperforms Adam and Adafactor in terms of validation accuracy and memory usage. CAME also improves BERT - Large training and has comparable performance to the baseline on downstream tasks with less memory cost. It works well for large batch training, extending existing memory - efficient optimizers.

The work introduces a framework called RoHT, Reasoning over Hierarchical Question Decomposition Tree, for explainable question answering. It aims to answer complex questions and provide explanations. It addresses limitations of neuro - symbolic and decompose - based methods. RoHT is a two - stage framework. First, it builds a Hierarchical Question Decomposition Tree, HQDT, for a complex question. Then, it does probabilistic reasoning over the HQDT to fuse knowledge from a knowledge base and a text corpus. It evaluates RoHT on KQA Pro and Musique datasets. On KQA Pro, RoHT outperforms existing KB QA methods with the incomplete KB and shows improvement with Wikipedia. On Musique, RoHT - text and RoHT - mix outperform TransferNet. RoHT shows the benefits of explicit decomposition and integrating knowledge from different sources.

Shangbin, a PhD student at the University of Washington, presented their work on political biases in language models. They found that language models are trained on large web crawl data, including well - covered political news media like New York Times and Los Angeles Times. This has both good and bad sides. On one hand, diverse perspectives are learned, celebrating democracy. But on the other hand, social biases in political opinions can lead to fairness issues in downstream tasks.Their study investigates the political bias propagation pipeline. The talk discusses different dependency structures in coordination. In universal dependencies and Igor Mel'čuk's theory, the first conjunct is the head. In Prague approach, the conjunction is the head. In Hudson's Word Grammar, all conjuncts are heads. The aim is to argue for symmetric structures against asymmetric ones. The argument is based on dependency length minimization. In English, direct objects prefer to be close to the verb. When the governor is on the left or absent, the left conjunct tends to be shorter. This tendency grows with the length difference between conjuncts. When the governor is on the right, this effect disappears. The paper provides evidence from the Penn Treebank and shows how this supports symmetric structures of coordination.

The work focuses on multi - attribute controllable dialogue generation. It addresses limitations of previous methods, like single - attribute focus and lack of unified evaluation. Contributions include DCG, a disentangled controllable generation model, and a unified reference - free evaluation framework, MAE. The model uses DialoGPT framework with compositional prompt module. It has attribute - oriented and task - oriented prompts. Experiments show DCG outperforms baselines in controllability and text equality. MAE is effective for evaluating different attribute granularities. The work proves the method's effectiveness in compositional generalization for multi - attribute controllable dialogue.
The authors of the paper are affiliated with Google Translate.

Jia-Huei Ju, a research assistant at Academia Sinica, presents their work on a compare - and - contrast multistage pipeline for uncovering financial signals in financial reports. They focus on the Form 10 - K annual report, which contains important company activities. Their work is motivated by the similarity of words and yearly - dependent contents in these reports. They introduce a highlighting task and a multi - stage pipeline. Stage 0 is document segmentation, Stage 1 is relation recognition, and Stage 2 and Stage 2+ are out - of - domain and in - domain fine - tuning. They classify pairs into three types: β, revised, and mismatched. For model tuning, they use eSNLI for out - of - domain fine - tuning and revised pairs for intermediate fine - tuning. They evaluate using precision, recall, and PCC. Their domain - adaptive highlighting model performs well on FINAL and eSNLI datasets. They also observe benefits on simulation with mismatched pairs. Future work includes improving effectiveness and adding more features.
The affiliations of the authors of the paper are Stony Brook University. If you have any other questions about the paper, feel free to ask.

The audio discusses challenges in domain adaptation for open - domain question answering. It uses the example of answering questions about Narora, Kakrapur, and Tarapur. The work aims to improve the performance of models when dealing with out - of - domain questions. It looks at different data interventions like zero - shot and few - shot methods. For zero - shot, it controls interactions among question, answer, and context. For few - shot, it uses examples from the target domain. The work also identifies types of dataset shift like no shift, concept shift, covariate shift, and full shift. It measures compatibility between source and target datasets and finds that few - shot adaptations are effective for most target datasets. Overall, it improves reader performance by up to 24%. The audio discusses the current challenges in grounded language understanding for language models. It points out that most models are pre - trained without grounding, which makes the task difficult. Existing research often uses language models to directly generate plans, but this can lead to ungrammatical or invalid plans. The speaker proposes a novel framework called Pangu. In this framework, a symbolic agent proposes candidate plans, and a language model scores and ranks them. This way, the language model doesn't have to handle the validity and grammar of the plan. Pangu shows good performance across different settings and has strong sample efficiency. It also has strong generalizability under non - i.i.d. settings. The speaker suggests that discrimination might be a better strategy for grounded language understanding than generation. They invite discussions and collaborations.
The authors experimented on four datasets: AG News, MIND, SST2, and Enron Spam. If you have any other questions about this paper or anything else, feel free to let me know.

The content is about a joint work on detecting improvable claims for argumentative writing support. It starts by introducing text revision as an essential part of professional writing, especially in argumentative writing. It then presents two tasks: Suboptimal-Claim detection and Claim Improvement Suggestion. The work explores challenges in working with revision - based data, like representativity and reliability, model complexity and architecture, dependence on contextual information, and topical and user bias. It concludes that revision - based data can be effectively used for the tasks and that modeling the distance between versions is helpful for detecting suboptimal claims. For more details, one should refer to the paper.

Simultaneous speech translation, SimulST, is translating spoken language into text in another language in real time. Current models have problems like long training procedures and need different models for different latencies. The paper proposes EDAtt, Encoder - Decoder Attention. It uses existing offline ST models without re - training. It decides whether to emit partial translation based on attention. If the sum of cross - attention is below a certain threshold, it emits a word. The results show it outperforms other strategies in terms of translation quality and latency. The paper also released open - source code and models for reproducibility. If you want to know more, you can read the paper.

The prompting strategy has a big impact on the performance of LLMs for translation. In a simple experiment, using one-shot prompting with two different prompts for each sentence, the majority of sentences, 516 out of 1, 000, showed a difference of more than one BLEURT point. In extreme cases, the difference could go up to 40 BLEURT points. So, it's really important to select a good prompting strategy.

The authors propose a diagnostic test suite for knowledge integration. They introduce a coreference resolution task to probe for the ability to draw on knowledge available in different sources.

Yebowen Hu from the University of Central Florida presents MeetingBank, a new benchmark dataset for meeting summarization. It includes City Council meeting transcripts, reference summaries, and URLs. Data collection uses Speechmatics API for audio to text conversion. The dataset has 1,366 meetings and 7,000 instances. It measures coverage and density of summaries. For model evaluation, top summarization systems like BART - Large, Pagasus, and GPT - 3 are compared. GPT - 3 shows high fluency and coherence but lower informativeness and factuality. MeetingBank is a useful tool for researchers and provides insights into decision - making in City Council.

The audio discusses a paper on early misinformation detection for COVID - 19 treatments. It points out that existing approaches often have unrealistic evaluations and are not human - centric. The paper proposes a human - in - the - loop evaluation framework. It has two main components: one for detecting misleading claims and the other for policy violation verification. The system uses a T5 model for claim extraction and a BERT - based model for stance classification. The evaluation shows that the system can detect unapproved treatments early and has a high accuracy in policy violation verification. It also provides a human - workload metric. The work aims to motivate future human - in - the - loop misinformation detection systems.

The work presents a two - step pipeline for finding high - agreement Amazon Mechanical Turk, MTurk, Workers for summarization. It starts with qualification settings, including pre - task qualifications like location, number of HITs, and HIT Approval Rate. The qualification task has two stages. The first stage tests annotators' ability to evaluate multiple dimensions correctly, categorizing them into gold, silver, bronze, and block. Only gold and silver workers pass. The second stage tests capacity for handling heavy workload. The reference - based task tests general performance on true annotation tasks. The pipeline workers show high agreement. Baseline MTurk workers use a statistical filter called MACE, but have incomplete HIT coverage. CloudResearch MTurk workers have lower task acceptance rate. The pipeline results in 6% of 200 participants being gold and silver. It's a best practice for high - agreement annotations at large scale and lower cost. Limitations include only English summarization on MTurk and no guarantee for training of correctness. Google provided the experiment funding.
Yes, the code is available on GitHub.

Jiho Kim from KAIST AI presented their paper "FACTKG: Fact Verification via Reasoning on Knowledge Graphs". They introduced a new task, Knowledge Graph-Based Fact Verification, as there was no existing dataset using knowledge graphs for evidence with natural language claims. They proposed a new dataset, FactKG, which uses DBpedia. Claims are in two styles: written and colloquial. There are two labels: SUPPORTED and REFUTED. The task involves retrieving evidence from DBpedia and verifying claims using reasoning like one - hop, conjunction, existence, multi - hop, and negation. They used a colloquial style transfer model and presupposition templates for practical use. They constructed baselines, including Claim Only and GEAR model. The GEAR model outperformed all baselines. You can download the dataset and contact Jiho Kim.

The annotators for NLPositionality were not balanced in regard to each demographic. They came from 87 countries, which is a large number, but it doesn't necessarily mean they were balanced in terms of gender, education level, etc. The study aimed to get a rich set of demographic data by re-annotating data sets with diverse annotators, but it doesn't seem to have achieved perfect balance in all demographics. If you want to know more about the demographics of the annotators, you could check out their dashboard for the most updated analysis results.

Sai Kiran Tanikella, a master's student at IIT Kanpur, presents "U - CREAT: Unsupervised Case Retrieval using Events extrAcT". Legal professionals face challenges with increasing case volume. The Prior Case Retrieval task aims to retrieve relevant cited documents from a pool. The work makes two key contributions: the IL - PCR dataset and the U - CREAT pipeline.The IL - PCR dataset is a new benchmark for PCR tasks, with 7, 070 legal cases and 6. 775 average citations per query. It has a larger pool of cases, longer documents, larger vocabulary, and more citations compared to COLIEE'21.The U - CREAT pipeline uses unsupervised learning and an event - based approach. Event extraction is crucial, using dependency parsing. The pipeline has high efficiency and generalizes across legal systems. It uses event - based models, with the Event Filtered Docs model performing best. U - CREAT outperforms existing approaches, including a recent supervised method. It opens up avenues for further exploration in prior case retrieval. For more details, check out the paper.

Mario Ezra Aragón presents "DisorBERT", a model for detecting mental disorders in social media. Mental disorders are psychological syndromes causing distress and disability. Social media offers a chance to study mental health issues. The work aims to automatically analyze social media posts for mental health disorder detection. Domain adaptation is used to improve model performance on specific domains like Reddit and mental health. The approach involves a base language model, integrating Reddit and mental health info, and using a lexicon for masking. Results on eRisk datasets show DisorBERT's good balance in precision and recall. Examples show DisorBERT focuses on words related to mental disorders. The model's effectiveness is compared to MentalBERT. Future work includes exploring different lexical resources and using clinical data.

The research presents a framework for document - level relation extraction with uncertainty - guided label denoising. It aims to improve the quality of distant supervision, DS, data. A pre - denoising DocRE model is trained with both DS and human - annotated data to generate pseudo labels. Uncertainty estimation is introduced to determine if model predictions can be trusted. An instance - level uncertainty estimation method is proposed for overlapping relations. A re - labeling strategy with dynamic class uncertainty thresholds is designed to filter pseudo labels with high uncertainty. A multi - phase training strategy is also developed to iteratively re - label DS data. The framework outperforms several strong baselines on public datasets. The main contributions include the uncertainty - guided label denoising framework, instance - level uncertainty estimation for overlapping relations, an iterative re - labeling strategy with dynamic class uncertainty thresholds, and great performance improvements.

The speaker, Chiang Cheng - Han, introduces a new work about using large language models for evaluating text quality in natural language processing. They propose using large language models to rate samples based on instructions. They mention related work like G - Eval but state their idea was novel at submission. The motivation is to find an alternative to human evaluation, which is unstable and hard to reproduce. They conduct an experiment rating stories generated by GPT - 2 and written by humans on grammar, coherence, likability, and relevance. They use human English teachers as ground - truth for comparison. Two large language models, Davinci and ChatGPT, show a clear preference for human - written text. The speaker encourages further questions and invites to read the paper or visit their poster stand at ACL.

Yusen Zhang from Penn State University presents their work on XSemPLR, a cross-lingual semantic parsing system. Semantic parsing builds semantic representations like SQL and Lambda Calculus. Cross-lingual semantic parsing translates queries in multiple languages into representations. Existing models have limited coverage, especially for Chinese and certain meaning representations. XSemPLR provides a unified dataset with 9 datasets, 5 tasks, 8 representations, and 22 languages. It has six evaluation settings: Translate-Test, Monolingual Model, Monolingual Few-shot, Multilingual Model, Cross-lingual Zero-shot, and Few-shot transfer. Monolingual models like Encoder-PTR and Encoder-Decoder are evaluated. Encoder-Decoder performs best on all datasets. Cross-lingual transfer shows significant performance gap in Zero-shot but is reduced with Few-shot. XSemPLR is a comprehensive benchmark for cross-lingual semantic parsing. It shows interesting findings like the "Curse of Multilinguality" and the effectiveness of pretraining on English. The work is presented in a paper and code.

The work focuses on mitigating label biases in in - context learning for text classification. It identifies three types of label biases: vanilla - label bias, context - label bias, and domain - label bias. Experiments show that random in - domain words from the task corpus can bias model predictions, while random English words don't. Domain - context calibration is proposed to handle biases. It uses random in - domain words to estimate and calibrate the model's bias. This method improves in - context learning performance, especially on tasks with large domain - label bias. It outperforms previous calibration methods. The work aims to systematically investigate label bias problems and improve large language models' in - context learning. For more details, check the paper.

Lin Wang, a Zhejiang University grad student, presents his paper "TAVT: Towards Transferable Audio-Visual Text Generation". He notes that uni - model text gen tasks like machine translation and image captioning have advanced due to large - scale pre - training and big models. But multimodal tasks like audio - visual text gen face data annotation challenges and domain shifts. He proposes Transferable Audio - Visual Text Generation to overcome these. The main challenge is multi - modal domain shifts like visual style and audio energy. He posits a unified audio semantic space for aligning visual concepts across domains.The framework has three components: an audio - visual meta - mapper network, an encoder and language model generator, and counterfactual contrastive learning. The meta - mapper network maps visual concepts to a unified audio semantic space. The encoder and generator use a transformer - based approach with an alpha to evaluate modality contributions. A Dual Counterfactual Contrastive Learning is proposed for better visual - textual alignment.The experiments on MSVD and MSR - VTT benchmarks show TAVT outperforms SOTA models on cross - datasets and cross - domain settings, even on low - resource domains. Ablation experiments analyze the impact of audio features on performance.

Ananya and Vignesh presented their work on "IndicMT Eval", a dataset for evaluating machine translation metrics for Indian languages. They focused on five Indian languages, Tamil, Malayalam, Hindi, Marathi, and Gujarati. They selected 200 sentences from the Flores dataset and generated 1,400 candidate translations for each language using seven translation models. Bilingual expert annotators evaluated the translations, marking errors and providing overall scores. They analyzed various metrics, finding that COMET - based metrics had the highest correlations with human scores. They fine - tuned COMET using their dataset and found that IndicCOMET outperformed COMET baselines on three languages and was more robust on the ACES Translation Accuracy Challenge Sets. They made their dataset publicly available.

The "marked words" method draws upon the sociolinguistic concept of "markedness". It identifies words that distinguish marked groups from unmarked ones. It uses the Fightin’ Words method, which is basically using weighted log - odds ratios to distinguish the top words for each marked group. For example, for the personas of black women, it compares the log - odds ratios against both white personas and man personas. This method helps to identify the words that facilitate stereotypes and essentializing narratives.
The authors are affiliated with the University of Washington.

Shi Tao introduced his work "MultiEMO" for emotion recognition in conversations. He first talked about the task of emotion regulation in conversations, which aims to predict the emotion label of each utterance. He pointed out existing challenges like not fully exploiting multimodal information complementarity, poor performance on minority emotion classes, and difficulty distinguishing semantically similar emotions.Then, he proposed MultiEMO. It has four key components: unimodal feature extraction, context modeling, multimodal fusion, and emotion classification. He introduced VisExtNet for visual feature extraction, MultiAttn for multimodal fusion, and Sample - Weighted Focal Contrast loss for emotion classification. VisExtNet captures facial expressions without redundant scene info. MultiAttn integrates modalities through cross - attention. SWFC loss helps with minority and semantically similar emotions. Experiments on MELD and IEMOCAP showed state - of - the - art performance. However, VisExtNet can't distinguish speakers and irrelevant people, SWFC loss needs a large batch size on MELD, and performance in minority emotions is still worse than majority classes.

Kayo Yin and colleagues present a study on when translation requires context. They use CXMI and its extended version, Pointwise CXMI, to measure context usage. They analyze words with high P - CXMI in TED talk transcripts translated to 14 languages. They identify discourse phenomena like formality and lexical cohesion that need context. They create a MuDA tagger to identify these phenomena in a parallel corpus. When evaluating models with different metrics, context - aware models perform better for some phenomena but not others. DeepL is more accurate than Google Translate for document - level translation. This study helps in building a benchmark for document - level machine translation.

Xuekai Zhu presents "StoryTrans: Non - Parallel Story Author - Style Transfer with Discourse Representations and Content Enhancing" at ACL 2023. This work focuses on story - level style transfer, which is a step forward from token - or sentence - level studies. The main challenge is imitating author - specific discourse - level linguistic choices, like narrative techniques and styles associated with writing topics. To address this, StoryTrans is proposed. It learns discourse representations from source texts and combines them with style embeddings. A new training objective reduces stylistic features from discourse representations and enhances content preservation through two - stage generation. The first stage transfers source text with masked style - specific content keywords, and the second stage fills in correct style - specific contents. Extensive experiments on Chinese and English datasets show StoryTrans outperforms baselines in style control and content preservation. It can supplement short phrases to enrich storylines and rewrite sentences while maintaining source semantics. The data and code are available in the repo.
The Prague approach.

Peng Tianshuo from Wuhan University presented a paper on FSUIE at ACL's Main Conference 4,915. It addresses issues in span - based UIE models like overreliance on annotated span boundaries and mismatch between transformer feature extraction and information extraction. FSUIE proposes a fuzzy span mechanism. The span boundaries are fuzzy instead of precise, and the attention for span extraction is adaptive. It uses a fuzzy span loss and fuzzy span attention. Experiments on named entity recognition, relationship extraction, and aspect sentiment triplet extraction show FSUIE's effectiveness. It achieves new state - of - the - art results in some tasks. The ablation study shows the benefits of FSL and FSA. The paper concludes that FSUIE has great potential in information extraction tasks.

Mingqi Gao from Peking University presents their work on factual error correction for dialogue summarization. They discuss two main solutions: introducing factuality - related objectives in the training or inference process, and designing an independent FEC model. FEC models are evaluated using factuality metrics like FactCC and DAE, but these have flaws. The current evaluation is vague and may not be reliable. The authors argue that introducing manually annotated reference corrections is necessary. They propose a new taxonomy of factual errors, with content - based and form - based classifications. Their evaluation framework, based on ERRANT, has three steps: alignment, classification, and comparison. They find that training FEC models with reference summaries from dialogue summarization datasets gives the best results. They also suggest combining human - annotated data with synthetic data. Current FEC models struggle with certain types of factual errors.
